parameters: \pop[2]We walk down the streets as a group, heading toward the town square.
\pop[2]The message that \c[10]Hermes\c[0] sent was clear; but were people listening?
\pop[2]It had to make a difference. There was so much on the line.
\pop[2]If people banded together, they could feed the \c[10]zeros\c[0] until \c[10]Hermes\c[0] took action.
\pop[2]But if anything would stop them, it'd be the fear of repercussions from \c[23]Argus\c[0].
\pop[2]By extension, would \c[23]Argus\c[0] be responsible if anything went wrong here?
\pop[4]You know, I've been here for a couple weeks now.
But this town square \c[14]never\c[0] fails to amaze me.
So I guess the figurative grass is greener?
\pop[3]Weird how your perspective can change so fast, isn't it?
\pop[4]Not as weird as letting a phone define your social status.
I mean, \c[14]this\c[0] is the only thing that separates you from the \c[10]zeros\c[0]?
\pop[2]He holds up his phone, and looks at it in confusion.
\pop[4]I didn't really know \c[14]what\c[0] to expect when I came to the city.
But our differences are such a fine line, they might as well not exist.
\pop[3]I think that's what \c[10]Hermes\c[0] is playing at.
\pop[4]It's weird how I realized it almost immediately.
\c[23]Argus\c[0] has been in power for almost a hundred years, right?
You think someone would've stepped up by now.
\pop[3]Well, it's hard to think outside the box when you're stuck in it.
You were \c[14]born\c[0] outside of it, though. Changes the way you think.
\pop[4]Maybe that's why they kept us outside?
Our presence is already changing public opinion.
There's nothing more dangerous than an open mind.
Especially when you're used to filling them with your own narrative.
\pop[4]You mean all of our thoughts could be placed there by \c[23]Argus\c[0]?
But that'd be more like... propaganda.
\pop[3]That's what you called the anniversary report, isn't it?
Look how much your mind has changed after seeing another perspective.
Dante of a few weeks ago would've \c[14]never\c[0] played along with this.
\pop[3]My mods at home don't seem that bad now, do they?
\pop[3]Are you really using this as an opportunity to clear yourself?
\pop[3]Hey, I gotta take what I can get.
\pop[2]A few moments later, we round the corner and see the town square.
\pop[2]Suffice it to say, the sight we're greeted to is... less than inspiring.
\pop[2]The gathering of \c[10]zeros\c[0] is still there, but it all looks the same.
\pop[2]For some reason, I expected the sight of unity.
\pop[2]I expected to see defiant souls feeding the \c[10]zeros\c[0].
\pop[2]Defiant, but also hopeful in their rebellion.
\pop[2]Instead, I see a couple bowls of fruit scattered near the \c[10]zeros\c[0].
\pop[2]Barely anybody helped, and they must've fled as soon as they did.
\pop[2]It looks like the children were given piority, as they're all eating apples.
\pop[2]But they all look so weak. The support wasn't enough for everybody...
Especially with public opinion the way it is.
\pop[3]Yeah, but online polls can only be so reliable.
A lot of people are all talk, with no action.
\pop[4]I bet they're all waiting until the fifth...
A small trickle is a lot easier to take care of.
It'd be way easier if everybody showed up at once.
They have the power to stop this right now.
But every second they don't? Well, you get the idea.
\pop[3]Way too risky, especially if they're watching us.
Every move we make, has to be extremely calculated.
\pop[3]In what way is a huge New Year's Eve party "extremely calculated"?
\pop[3]It's easier to blend into a big crowd.
I think that's why \c[10]Hermes\c[0] set a specific date and time, too.
There's going to be so many people here on the fifth.
\pop[4]You know, I came here for an inspiring sight...
But now I'm just depressed. What should we do?
Are there any \c[10]zeros\c[0] you want to go see?
\pop[4]I feel like I've betrayed them, in a way.
I have what they want, but I can't share it.
\pop[4]Until we're all equal, I don't think I can look them in the eye.
It'd just be a constant reminder of how helpless we both are.
\pop[3]Don't worry, this'll all be over soon.
Then we can throw a big party, alright?
\pop[3]I'm totally down for that. Introductions are in order, Kyron.
Those are your people; your friends. I'd like to meet them.
How'd you all get into the city anyway?
\pop[4]It was \c[10]Hermes\c[0]. I don't know much about the specifics, though.
They helped the leader of my colony cheat \c[23]The System\c[0] somehow.
Made it so that we could all just walk in, without setting off alarms.
Security around the city walls is top-notch.
Far greater than the Triple R, or The Wayfarer.
\pop[4]It actually feels like \c[10]Hermes\c[0] might be able to pull this off.
Did you meet them, Kyron? What were they like?
I don't know if the colony leader did, either.
They always operated from the shadows.
\pop[4]Kinda like how they spoke to us in Isaac's store.
They kept their identity shrouded in mystery.
\pop[4]But I think it's better that way, actually.
A shadow can be a \c[14]lot\c[0] more threatening than a face.
If I were \c[23]Argus\c[0], I'd be shaking in my boots right now.
\pop[2]We all nod, and start to walk toward the Triple R.
\pop[2]There'd be plenty of time to get a meal in before we head back home.
\pop[2]I feel bad, eating a huge meal while the \c[10]zeros\c[0] are starving out here...
\pop[2]I remember Taylor saying something similar in our group chat a while ago.
\pop[2]There's only one thing I can really do. Just... hope that this all ends in their favor.
\pop[2]As we walk past them however, something catches my eye.
\pop[2]It's that child, carrying the doll with them.
\pop[2]The one I saw before I got to The Wayfarer...
\pop[2]Their skipping seems a lot less gleeful this time around.
\pop[2]There's a smile on their face, but not as wide as last time.
\pop[2]In their hand is an apple, with a few bites taken out of it.
\pop[2]They notice me watching, and our eyes soon lock.
\pop[2]They give me a quick smile before they get back to what they were doing.
\pop[2]Before long, they stop skipping, and walk over to a pair of adults.
\pop[2]They embrace each other. They're clearly the parents.
\pop[2]I can't believe how emaciated they look. It makes my heart sink.
\pop[2]Living on whatever scraps they can find for \c[14]weeks\c[0] now...?
\pop[2]Yet still, the child smiles; almost unable to comprehend the situation.
\pop[2]I remember being like that. Not being able to see the world for what it is...
\pop[2]I wonder what it was - the thing that made us lose our childlike sense of wonder.
\pop[2]As we round the corner, I simply hope that this child never has to find out.
\pop[2]But in a world so unforgiving, I fear it was only a matter of time...
